title: Pulling the Linkmobile back into the garage
html:
As a follow-up to Tuesday's post, I've disabled the nightly link post as of now and turned off the links category on the main page template.

I got a surprising amount of good and friendly feedback on the change in comments, IMs, and emails. And, the balance to me sounds like there are people who sorta liked the change and a lot of people just plain turned off by it—the nays were louder than the yeas. I was on the fence, leaning toward dislike, so down go the links.

I'd still like to reintegrate my link posting output on del.icio.us into this site in some other fashion soon, because that's where the bulk of my hasty blogging happens these days. In the course of writing this new book, I've got a panoply of other options available from sidebars to AJAX-powered geegaws. I've also considered pulling FeedMagick into the mix to offer a "build your own" remixed feed option, but I've not yet had the ambition to deliver on that.

So sorry link fans, it's back to the status quo for me, for now.
body:
As a follow-up to [Tuesday's post][tp], I've disabled the nightly link post as of now and turned off the links category on the main page template.  

I got a surprising amount of good and friendly feedback on the change in comments, IMs, and emails.  And, the balance to me sounds like there are people who *sorta* liked the change and a lot of people just plain turned off by it—the nays were louder than the yeas.  I was on the fence, leaning toward dislike, so down go the links.

I'd still like to reintegrate [my link posting output on del.icio.us][del] into this site in some other fashion soon, because that's where the bulk of my hasty blogging happens these days.  In the course of writing [this new book][book], I've got a panoply of other options available from sidebars to AJAX-powered geegaws.  I've also considered pulling [FeedMagick][] into the mix to offer a "build your own" remixed feed option, but I've not yet had the ambition to deliver on that.

So sorry link fans, it's back to the status quo for me, for now.

<!-- tags: metablogging links delicious ajax feedmagick geegaws -->

[del]: http://del.icio.us/deusx
[tp]: http://decafbad.com/blog/2006/02/07/hows-my-link-driving
[FeedMagick]: http://decafbad.com/trac/wiki/FeedMagick
[book]: http://decafbad.com/blog/2005/12/14/hacking-delicious-is-a-real-book

title: links for 2006-02-09
html:
• 365 tomorrows - Seeing is Believing
    "He could barely hear them over the colors and shapes of the room. "...a new vision thanks to sight based on""
    (tags: scifi writing fiction)
  • Lappy 486 - Strong Bad Email #143
    It's Strong Bad's intro to technology!
    (tags: funny flash cartoons)
  • Lappy 486 - Strong Bad Email #144
    Wherein Strong Bad narrates every day lives as movies
    (tags: flash funny cartoons)
  • Clearbits - SOME RANDOM DUDE
    "Clearbits is a small spinoff of the Bitcons icon set that allows for CSS-based coloring and framing."
    (tags: webdev icons images)
  • futurilla: Joshua Schachter of del.icio.us
    "JS is talking about what they've learned in building del.icio.us"
    (tags: delicious)
  • Raw - del.icio.us Reading Lists
    "Ok, a quick way of collecting a list of resources is to use del.cio.us through its bookmarklet. So I'll find a few feeds (the feeds, not the blogs) and tag them "readinglist"."
    (tags: opml delicious readinglists rss xsl xml)
  • Tim Anderson's ITWriting - SOAP is insane, says Del.icio.us founder
    "One fun remark: avoid using "SOAP, Corba or something insane" for your API - del.icio.us doesn't even use REST, Schachter said, but rather POX - plain old XML. His logic is that simple APIs are available to a larger subset of developers - why limit your
    (tags: webservices delicious soap rest pox)
  • Recap: Becoming an Email Ninja | 43 Folders
    "...one of the issues that consistently draws the most folks here is anything that helps them deal with email."
    (tags: email productivity gtd)
  • Fifty (50!) Tools which can help you in Writing - lifehack.org
    "Roy Peter Clark from Poynter Institute has posted up 50 tools that can help you when you do any kinds of writing. This is a extensive list of writing tools, but by no mean you need to apply all of them when you do any writing."
    (tags: lifehack writing tips howto)
  • Anne 2.0: Churning and Burning
    "We need new paradigms for following what's happening in the blogosphere."
    (tags: metablogging attention)
  • Scripting for the Semantic Web SFSW2006
    "The workshop aims to bring together developers of the RDF base infrastructure for scripting languages with practitioners building applications using these languages."
    (tags: scripting programminf semweb rdf)
  • The Scientific Activist: Reporting from the Crossroads of Science and Politics: BREAKING NEWS: George Deutsch Did Not Graduate From Texas A & M University
    "Through my own investigations I have just discovered that George Deutsch, the Bush political appointee at the heart of administration efforts to censor NASA scientists (most notably to prevent James Hansen from speaking out about global warming), did not
    (tags: politics bush science nasa morons)
  • A Young Bush Appointee Resigns His Post at NASA - New York Times
    "George C. Deutsch, the young presidential appointee at NASA who told public affairs workers to limit reporters' access to a top climate scientist and told a Web designer to add the word "theory" at every mention of the Big Bang, resigned yesterday, agenc
    (tags: nasa science bush politics)
  • Penny Arcade! - The Sporting Life
    "I heard the refs were paid off by ... Gay Democrats? I don't know. Who do we not like?"
    (tags: sports football comics gaming)
  • Sci-Fi Hi-Fi - Blog Archive JSON is so hot right now!
    "Awhile ago it dawned on me that JSON bears more than a passing resemblance to old-school NeXT plists, and that it would be pretty natural to write an NSDictionary category that could deserialize a JSON string into a Cocoa object graph."
    (tags: cocoa json webdev mac apple next)
  • blakeseely.com - Blog » Blog Archive » +[NSDictionary dictionaryWithJSONString:]
    "...since JSON is basically a series of key-value pairs, it would be a good match for NSDictionary - and it should be easy to create a dictionary out of a JSON string."
    (tags: cocoa objc mac osx json apple webdev)
  • CocoaJSON
    "Blake Seely released some code yesterday to convert Cocoa datatypes to JSON. I've had similar code that Ive been meaning to put online for a while now. So now the world has gone from zero to two Cocoa code-bases to read/write JSON."
    (tags: cocoa apple objc programming webdev osx)
  • Cocoa, JSON & Turbogears
    "This post discusses how to use Cocoa to communicate with Turbogears powered web-applications."
    (tags: python objc cocoa mac osx apple programming webdev)
  • Phil Windley's Technometria | Using Google's Universal Authentication Engine
    "With no fanfare at all, Google has created a universal login for anyone who wants to use it."
    (tags: google gtalk jabber webdev programming security)
  • Information Wants To Be Free » Blog Archive » Working on the book: lessons learned so far
    "At this point, I can’t even imagine what life would be like if I didn’t spend every weekend doing research and writing. I mean, I do something book-related almost every day, so it’s completely sewn into the fabric of my life."
    (tags: writing books)
  • The Cult of Mac Blog
    "Suddenly, it all made sense: the hundreds of calls, the dead air, the gurgling sounds. Babies. They were picking up the receiver and pressing a button at the bottom of the handset."
    (tags: woz apple funny)
  • Wired News: Forget Jobs, Let's Worship Woz
    "this week I figured I'd balance things out by talking about someone I admire greatly: Steve Wozniak."
    (tags: apple wozniak woz)

title: links for 2006-02-08
html:
• Lorelle on WordPress - More Must-Have Bookmarklets Than You Can Swing a Browser At
    "I thought I'd do you better and offer you more must-have javascript bookmarklets than you can swing a bookmarklet at - if you could swing a bookmarklet. Can you?"
    (tags: javascript bookmarklets)
  • Bad Astronomy Blog » Blog Archive » Outrage at attacks on NASA science
    "NASA is not in the business of teaching religion. They should be teaching science, and the Big Bang is definitely science."
    (tags: astronomy nasa religion bush politics)
  • Thoughtless for the Day: She Blinded Me with Acid
    "This is why, if you think about it, celebrating Darwin Day is more than just a good idea: it's your patriotic duty."
    (tags: darwin science religion)
  • Achewood - February 7, 2006
    "I ain't need no Dell Inspiron to bust a man down on into his component pieces."
    (tags: achewood comics funny)
  • RSS: Guidelines for reading lists
    "A few ideas as they occur about the developing art of reading lists."
    (tags: opml readinglists newsriver)
  • OPod
    "The OPML-Pod is an AJAX OPML and RSS viewer widget that you can embed in any web page you like."
    (tags: opml rss javascript webdev)
  • Russell Beattie Notebook - No Comments Pushback
    "Anyways, as I've repeated from the very beginning in response to all sorts of criticism over the years, I will publish this weblog how I want, about what I want and you read if you want. Thats it, very simple."
    (tags: metablogging)
  • Amy's OPML blog: Tuesday, February 07, 2006
    "It's going to give people a bad impression of reading lists if they try the concept and end up feeling inundated."
    (tags: readinglists opml rss aggregators)
  • LEGO Technic Difference Engine
    "I set out to build a working Difference Engine using LEGO parts which could compute 2nd or 3rd order polynomials to 3 or 4 digits."
    (tags: lego compsci hacks hardware)
  • Boing Boing: Legend of Zelda pixelblocks
    "Nintendo has released a commemorative set of Legend of Zelda pixelblocks to celebrate the game's 20th anniversary."
    (tags: gaming nes nintendo zelda nifty)
  • Boing Boing: Halliburton to build "immigration detention centers" in US
    "Call me paranoid, but seeing "Halliburton," "Homeland Security," and "detention centers" in the same article doesn't make me feel safe at all."
    (tags: politics bush war halliburton scary)
  • Wired News: Podfading Takes Its Toll
    Maybe it's better to expect podcasts to be less of a regular thing like radio, more like a series of limited runs.
    (tags: podcasting)
  • Paolo Valdemarin Weblog - My ideal RSS reader
    "My problem is that I'm not getting what I would really like from any of the available readers."
    (tags: rss hackingfeeds aggregators)
  • Raw - Ideal RSS Readers
    "I'm becoming increasingly convinced that extending (human-readable) content-oriented approach is the quickest path to a more generalised data-oriented (i.e. Semantic) web."
    (tags: rss hackingfeeds aggregators)
  • WP lightbox JS WordPress plugin
    "WP lightbox JS is a WordPress plugin that enable you to use lightbox JS script to overlay images on the current page."
    (tags: metablogging webdev ajax)
  • ESBN - Electronic Standard Book Number
    Heard about this on the TWiT podcast from Leo. Maybe I'm missing something, but isn't this what URLs and URIs are for?
    (tags: webdev publishing)

title: links for 2006-02-06
html:
• TRAXMOD SD Card MOD Player
    "The current dsPIC based prototype can play 4 channel MOD music files at 24KHz 9 bit, stereo, using a dsPIC30F4013 and SD Card." Wow, where were these back when I was composing on my Amiga? :)
    (tags: mods music nifty gadgets hacks hardware)
  • Micro Persuasion: Bye Bye Email Marketing, Hello RSS
    "That's all folks. The door has officially closed on email marketing. Maybe this will drive more companies to start up opt-in RSS feeds and blogs that facilitate dialogue."
    (tags: marketing rss hackingfeeds email spam)
  • Jeff Barr’s Blog » A Few Words on Technology Evangelism
    "I hope that is it clear from what I have written that technology evangelism is a whole lot of fun." This does sound like a fun job, though I wonder if I could be happy evangelizing just one technology.
    (tags: amazon technology evangelism webservices)
  • google-snack-room.jpg (JPEG Image, 1024x768 pixels) - Scaled (82%)
    This makes me want to work at Google :)
    (tags: google snacks)
  • haircut.jpg (JPEG Image, 500x375 pixels)
    Awesome haircut that looks like a baseball hat with a brim
    (tags: haircut images)

    "The current dsPIC based prototype can play 4 channel MOD music files at 24KHz 9 bit, stereo, using a dsPIC30F4013 and SD Card." Wow, where were these back when I was composing on my Amiga? :)

title: links for 2006-02-05
html:
• Anne 2.0: Ning: Great for Mediocre Programmers
    "I spent some time playing with Ning today. I couldn't believe how easy it was to parse an OPML file and display it on a web page."
    (tags: ning webdev)
  • Scripting News: 2/3/2006 - It's a different world today
    "But none of that means that I can't find enough users for my aggregator, and you for yours, to be able to continue development and influence the market, because we don't have to convince the editors of PC Mag and PC Week that our products matter. ... Now
    (tags: nifty webdev programming syndication rss aggregators)
  • BBC NEWS | Technology | Gaming glamour tempts tennis pro
    "Scotsman David Kinnaird is swapping his tennis racket for a railgun."
    (tags: gaming quake)
  • Wymsey Weekend: A Guide to Mobile Cooking
    "we show you how to use two mobile phones to cook an egg which will make a change from phoning out for a pizza." Eggs == brains?
    (tags: mobile cooking)
  • Nelson's Weblog: culture / games / emulation / noahsArk3D
    "Instead of a soldier shooting evil Nazis with machine guns, you're Noah lobbing sleep-inducing berries at unruly goats on the Ark. Yes, really."
    (tags: gaming snes id christianity)
  • BlogicBlog: View from the trenches: The techie way of liberating the podcast URL from iTunes
    "Jon Udell is not happy about having to transcribe podcast URLs that iTunes displays, but does not allow to copy. While the general point about lock-in is good, here is a quick techie workaround in a meanwhile."
    (tags: itunes stanford podcasts)
  • 01 - South Side of the Sky.mp3 (audio/mpeg Object)
    Awesome cover of Yes' "South Side of the Sky", with all parts done by one girl.
    (tags: nelljames mp3 music audio yes covers rock)
  • 04 - Madrigal.mp3 (audio/mpeg Object)
    Another Yes cover with Nell James doing all the parts
    (tags: nelljames music mp3 yes)
  • The Music of Nell James
    "Welcome to the official website of musician Nell James (previously known as Nell & the Nellettes), 17 year old multi-instrumentalist and composer."
    (tags: nelljames music)
  • NPR : Al Lewis, Beloved as 'Grandpa Munster,' Dies at 95
    "Al Lewis, the cigar-chomping patriarch of The Munsters whose work as a basketball scout, restaurateur and political candidate never eclipsed his role as Grandpa from the television sitcom, died after years of failing health. He was 95."
    (tags: sad)
  • O'Reilly Emerging Technology Conference - March 6-9, 2006 - San Diego, CA
    "> take proposal Okay. You have taken the proposal.

    "

    (tags: nifty grue conference etcon)

title: links for 2006-02-03
html:
• The Detroit Institute of Arts - AN EVENING WITH SHINICHIRO WATANABE - Wednesday, February 08, 2006 7:00 PM
    "The critically acclaimed animation (anime) director Shinichiro Watanabe will make a very special appearance at the Detroit Film Theatre,"
    (tags: anime detroit dft dia)
  • IEBlog : A New Look for IE
    Is it just me, or does this look like a GUI widget test demo? 3 different styles of buttons, in various colors, in seemingly random arrangement. Tabs squished in between other semi-related buttons. This is improvement?
    (tags: msft msie ie webdev windows ie7)
  • QDB: Quote #609240
    "One time my dad stole a roll of brightly-colored stickers from a butcher's counter that said "BREASTS" and went to the video store and stuck them on all the movies that looked likely to contain nudity."
    (tags: irc funny quotes)
  • ClickOnDetroit.com - LOCAL 4 FINANCE - Ikea To Bring Jobs, Shopping To Canton
    Hooray! "The Swedish home furnishings retailer is working toward a summer grand opening at its new location in Canton Township."
    (tags: ikea michigan canton shopping)
  • NASA - Apollo Chronicles: The Smell of Moondust
    "Why does it smell? How does it react with landers, rovers and habitats? What surprises await?"
    (tags: space moon science)
  • PHP: usort - Manual
    When I grouse about PHP not having good meta magic, here's a case in point: "Sort an array by values using a user-defined comparison function" My kingdom for an anonymous function or function reference or *something*
    (tags: php webdev programming)
  • Light and atoms get entangled (January 2006) - News - PhysicsWeb
    Ansible communications, here we come: "Physicists have for the first time entangled two atomic quantum bits, or "qubits", that are separated by long distances."
    (tags: physics future nifty)
  • Newspapers want search engines to pay | CNET News.com
    "The Internet has undercut the businesses of newspapers, book publishers and magazines for years and now these media are looking for ways to fight back." ...and in so doing, will cut their own throats.
    (tags: media publishing newspapers)
  • easing equations for dynamic tweening - ActionScript.org Forums
    "Here are the quadratic easing equations." Math for making things slide.
    (tags: flash javascript dhtml math ajax)
  • rentzsch.com: Stop Stop Stop Hurting the Internet
    "My God, they’ve made metal look good." ...and with a bonus quote and link to my link to the IE7 demo.
    (tags: msft msie vista gui safari apple webdev)
  • Kempa.com: Destroying History - Motown Building Razed for Super Bowl Parking
    "Before demolishing the building, the city couldn't be bothered to remove these artifacts. All sorts of historically important ephemera, knowingly demolished." As if I didn't have enough reasons to despise the Super Bowl and the Mayor
    (tags: detroit morons motown)
  • OPML Editor support: OPML Community Server Howto
    "How to install your own server"
    (tags: frontier opml webdev)
  • Joe Gregorio | BitWorking | Projects | httplib2.py
    "A comprehensive HTTP client library, httplib2.py supports many features left out of other HTTP libraries." Huzzah - some great updates beyond httpcache.py, a module from which I've gotten much mileage.
    (tags: http python)
  • Scott Sigler’s Podcast Novels - The Bloodcast » Infection, T-minus 5 weeks
    Massively slick production values on this podcast trailer for Scott Sigler's next upcoming run...
    (tags: podcasts scifi horror scottsigler)
  • Fantasy and Science Fiction - Fiction - KEYBOARD PRACTICE, CONSISTING OF AN ARIA WITH DIVERSE VARIATIONS FOR THE HARPSICHORD WITH TWO MANUALS
    "Got to force myself to sit down, sluice, educe the force that through these carpal tunnels drives the florid." Such an awesome story, reads like William Gibson mashed up with Douglas Hofstader.
    (tags: scifi writing stories)

Archived Comments

  • Martin Atkins
    2006-02-03T18:09:14

    If you want a laugh, you should take a look at PHP's create_function function...

  • l.m.orchard
    2006-02-04T02:03:18

    Gagh... this create_function function makes me sputter and curse.

  • Pete Prodoehl
    2006-02-02T19:54:33

    My Nokia phones lets me use any MP3 as a ringtone. I just transfer the file via Bluetooth from my Mac to the phone and select it. As I recall hearing, many phones/providers don't allow this because of all the potential money they can make off of selling ringtones.
body:
• Make your own Ringtones
    Remember to cut it down to mono. With this capability, I'm surprised there's a ringtone industry whatsoever.
    (tags: mobile ringtones)
  • BBC NEWS | UK | Speed-texter beats world record
    This, again, makes me wonder if some sort of morse code interface might be desirable on a mobile device?
    (tags: mobile sms records)
  • howto-qmail-procmail.txt
    Checking out how to get procmail working with qmail, in anticipation of setting up a moblog-by-email script.
    (tags: qmail procmail unix sysadmin)
  • jwz - GLTerminal
    "It's pretty sweet, though not as faithful a simulation of a CRT as Trevor Blackwell's fantastic Apple ][ screen saver (in xscreensaver)."
    (tags: nifty software hacks retro oldschool computing)
  • I blog therefore I am | Please Guido, pick me, pick me!
    Hee hee, I'm glad someone said it: "But hurry up, many leading web framework developers are pleading their case and you don't want to be last."
    (tags: webdev python)
  • 365 tomorrows - We All Fall Down
    "On the eighteenth day the sun didn't rise, we locked ourselves in our homes and apartments."
    (tags: scifi stories writing)
  • President Creates Cabinet-Level Position To Coordinate Scandals | The Onion - America's Finest News Source
    "In his State of the Union address to the nation last night, President Bush announced a new cabinet-level position to coordinate all current and future scandals facing his party."
    (tags: politics bush funny)
  • 0xDECAFBAD
    Friends don't let friends drink decaf.
    (tags: programming coffee caffeine)

Archived Comments

  • Pete Prodoehl
    2006-02-02T19:54:33

    My Nokia phones lets me use any MP3 as a ringtone. I just transfer the file via Bluetooth from my Mac to the phone and select it. As I recall hearing, many phones/providers don't allow this because of all the potential money they can make off of selling ringtones.

  • Anne Zelenka
    2006-02-01T19:16:40

    Geez, I don't know if I like that you're now posting your daily links. Your feed happens to be one of the first in my feedreader because it's in my favorites folder and because it starts with a zero (that was crafty of you). I can barely get beyond it because I'm clicking through on all these links. This stuff is not what I'd get from my other feeds so I can't count on seeing it elsewhere. Darn you to heck, Orchard.

  • l.m.orchard
    2006-02-01T23:16:51

    Anne: Heh, heh. You know, the 0 in my site's name wasn't planned for that purpose, but my alphabetic superiority has come in handy more than once. :)

    As for the links, I turned on the daily posting feature partly for research for the new book, but also because I felt like a big chunk of my daily brain dump was missing from here. But, I'm still trying to decide if I like these summaries, if they should be individual posts (as I'd originally intended and use sporadically on Hacking Feeds), or if they should stay separate.

    But, for what it's worth, if you'd like to spread the 0xDECAFBAD experience out over your reading lists, my WordPress install offers category feeds:

    • http://decafbad.com/blog/category/asides/feed
    • http://decafbad.com/blog/category/links/feed

    I keep meaning to document / display that somewhere... at any rate, nice to see you around here again!

title: Re-introducing nightly link posts
html: It feels all old-school like my first days of posting link blog entries, but I've added a "thingy" over at del.icio.us to schedule nightly posts from my day's bookmarking activity. I was feeling a bit of a lack here, since I completely detached my links from the site after the reboot this past fall. So, I hope you don't mind the new daily links—and if you do, tough. They're good for you. Like roughage.
body:
It feels all old-school like my first days of posting link blog entries, but I've [added a "thingy" over at del.icio.us][thingy] to schedule nightly posts from my day's bookmarking activity.  I was feeling a bit of a lack here, since I completely detached my links from the site after [the reboot this past fall][reboot].  So, I hope you don't mind the new daily links—and if you do, tough.  They're good for you.  Like roughage.

[thingy]: http://theory.isthereason.com/?p=499
[reboot]: http://decafbad.com/blog/2005/09/12/redesigninprogress
